examples: Care should be taken when holding babies.
I don't have a care in the world.

entries.meaning: The treatment of those in need (especially as a profession).
The state of being cared for by others.
The object of watchful attention or anxiety.

description: From Middle English caren, carien, from Old English carian (â€œto sorrow, grieve, be troubled, be anxious, to care for, heedâ€), from Proto-West Germanic *karÅn (â€œto careâ€), from Proto-Germanic *karÅnÄ… (â€œto careâ€).

Cognate with Middle High German karn (â€œto complain, lament, grieve, mournâ€), Alemannic German karen, kÃ¤ren (â€œto groan, wheeze, give a death rattleâ€), Swedish kÃ¤ra (â€œto fall in loveâ€), Icelandic kÃ¦ra (â€œto care, likeâ€), Gothic ğŒºğŒ°ğ‚ğ‰ğŒ½ (karÅn, â€œto be concernedâ€).

verbs.description: care (third-person singular simple present cares, present participle caring, simple past and past participle cared)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To be concerned (about), to have an interest (in); to feel concern (about).
examples: "She doesn't care what you think." "I don't care, I'm still going."

entries.meaning: (intransitive, polite, formal) To want, to desire; to like; to be inclined towards.
examples: Would you care for another slice of cake?
I don't care to hear your opinion.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal, by extension) For it to matter to, or make any difference to.
examples: An event aggregator facilitates a fire-and-forget model of communication. The object triggering the event doesn't care if there are any subscribers. It just fires the event and moves on.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) (with for) To look after or look out for.
examples: Young children can learn to care for a pet.
He cared for his mother while she was sick.
